line.title: Line
line.text: A line is a set of infinitely many points that extend forever in both directions. Lines are always straight and have no width.

polygon.title: Polygon
polygon.text: A polygon is geometric shape that is made up of straight line segments. Polygons cannot contain any curved sides, or holes. For example, a square is a polygon but a circle is not.

transformation.title: Transformation
transformation.text: A transformation converts one geometric shape into another. There are many different types of transformations, like reflections or dilations.

transformation-image.title: Image of a transformation
transformation-image.text: After transforming a geometric shape, the result is called its image. It is often denoted by adding a ’ to the end of its label.

rigid-transformation.title: Rigid transformation
rigid-transformation.text: A rigid transformation (or isometry) is a transformation that doesn't change the size or shape of a geometric figure.

translation.title: Translation
translation.text: A translation is a transformation that moves a figure in a specific direction, without changing its angle or shape.

reflection.title: Reflection
reflection.text: A reflection is a transformation that “flips” or “mirrors” a shape across a line.

rotation.title: Rotation
rotation.text: A rotation is a transformation that “turns” a shape by a certain angle around a fixed point.

polygon-vertex.title: Vertex of a polygon
polygon-vertex.text: The vertices of a polygon are the points where its adjacent sides meet (its “corners”).

center-of-rotation.title: Center of rotation
center-of-rotation.text: The center of rotation is the point around which a shape is being rotated.

function.title: Function
function.text: A function is a mathematical relation that converts an input x into exactly one output fx.

function-graph.title: Graphs of functions
function-graph.text: We can plot mathematical functions of the form fx in a coordinate system. The result is called the graph of the function.

congruent.title: Congruence
congruent.text: In geometry, two figures are congruent if are identical in size, shape and measure. This means we could move, flip or rotate them to exactly fit on top of each other.

symmetry.title: Symmetry
symmetry.text: A figure or shape has symmetry, if it looks the same after being transformed in some way (e.g. reflection or rotation).

reflectional-symmetry.title: Reflectional symmetry
reflectional-symmetry.text: A shape has reflectional symmetry if it looks the same after being reflected.

axis-of-symmetry.title: Axis of symmetry
axis-of-symmetry.text: If a shape has reflectional symmetry, the axis of symmetry is the line that divides it into two equal halves.

palindrome.title: Palindrome
palindrome.text: A palindrome is a word or number that reads the same from back to front as it does from front to back. For example, 25752 and “ANNA” are both palindromes.

dna.title: DNA
dna.text: DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is a molecule that contains the genetic blueprint of all living organisms. Most DNAs consist of two strands forming a double helix. Genetic information is encoded in the order of four nucleic acids (A, G, C and T) which make up the DNA. DNA sequencing is the process of extracting this information – an essential technique in biology, medicine, genetics and biotechnology.

rotational-symmetry.title: Rotational symmetry
rotational-symmetry.text: A shape has rotational symmetry if it looks the same after being rotated (by less than 360°).

order-of-symmetry.title: Order of symmetry
order-of-symmetry.text: If a shape has rotational symmetry, the order of symmetry is the number of orientations in which the shape looks the same. (Or, it is the number of times you can rotate the shape, before we get back to the start.)

square.title: Square
square.text: A square is a regular quadrilateral: all sides have the same length, and all angles have the same size (90°).

group.title: Group
group.text:
A group is a collection of “things” (like numbers or symmetries) that follow three different rules:

  1. You can add/combine two of the things, to get another one that is also in the group.
  2. The things are associative, which means that a+b+c+a+b+c.
  3. There is an identity, and every “thing” has an inverse which, when added, gives the identity.

translational-symmetry.title: Translational symmetry
translational-symmetry.text: A repeated pattern (like a wallpaper) has translational symmetry if it looks the same after being translated by a specific distance.

glide-reflection.title: Glide reflections
glide-reflection.text: A glide reflection is a special kind of transformation. It is a combination of a reflection and a translation in the same direction as the axis of reflection.

symmetry-group.title: Symmetry group
symmetry-group.text: The symmetry group of a geometric object is the collection of all of its symmetries (as well as the identity).

laws-of-nature.title: Laws of nature
laws-of-nature.text: The laws of nature are the name given collectively to the physical rules (usually expressed as mathematical equations) that try to explain everything we observe in the universe.

dilation.title: Dilation
dilation.text: A dilation is a transformation that resizes a geometric shape, by making it bigger or smaller.

scale-factor.title: Scale factor
scale-factor.text:
The scale factor of two similar geometric figures is the ratio of any two corresponding lengths.

A scale factor less than 1 indicates the shape is shrinked, and a scale factor greater than 1 indicates the shape is enlarged.

similar.title: Similar
similar.text: Two geometric shapes are similar if they have the same shape but a different size. We can move, rotate, reflect and resize one shape to match up with the other one. Their corresponding angles are equal and their corresponding sides are in the same ratio.

circle.title: Circle
circle.text: A circle is the set of all points in two dimensions, at a fixed distance (the radius) from a given point (the center).

equilateral-triangle.title: Equilateral triangle
equilateral-triangle.text: An equilateral triangle is a triangle in which all three sides have the same length.

congruent-angles.title: Congruent angles
congruent-angles.text: Two angles are congruent if they have the same size.

triangle-aa.title: AA condition for triangles
triangle-aa.text: Two triangles are similar if two of their angles have the same size. This is called the AA similarity condition for triangles.

associative.title: Associativity
associative.text: An operation • is associative if a•b•c=a•b•c. For example, both addition (+) and multiplication (×) of numbers is associative.
